contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=November 2008}} {{Politics of Greenland}} '''Politics of [[Greenland]]''' takes place in a framework of a [[parliamentary system|parliamentary]] [[representative democracy|representative democratic]] [[Denmark|Danish]] [[Dependent territory|dependency]].<ref name=PR-type>[http://www.electionguide.org/country.php?ID=86 ''Greenland Country Profile'' ] International Foundation for Electoral Systems (IFES) ElectioGuide</ref> The [[Prime Minister of Greenland|Prime Minister]] is the [[head of government]], and of a [[multi-party system]]. Greenland is a self-governing overseas administrative division of Denmark since 1979. [[Executive power]] is exercised by the government. [[Legislative power]] is vested in both the [[government]] and the [[Parliament of Greenland]] (known as Inatsisartut). The party system is dominated by the social democratic [[Forward (Greenland)|Forward]], the separatist and socialist [[Inuit Community]] and the conservative liberal and unionist [[Feeling of Community]]. The [[judiciary]] is independent of the executive and the legislature. ==Executive branch== The monarch of [[Denmark]] is also head of state of Greenland. She is represented by a High Commissioner, appointed by her. The Prime Minister is elected by Parliament and leads the Landsstyre. {{office-table}} |Queen |[[Margarethe II of Denmark]] | |14 January 1972 |- |High Commissioner |[[Mikaela Engell]] | |1 April 2005 |- |[[Prime Minister of Greenland|Prime Minister]] |[[Aleqa Hammond]] |[[Siumut]] |12 June 2009 |} ==Legislative branch== Greenland has a [[unicameral]] [[Parliament]] or ''[[parliament of Greenland|Landsting]]'' (31 seats; members are elected by popular vote on the basis of proportional representation to serve four-year terms). Two representatives were elected to the [[Parliament of Denmark]] at the last Danish elections, [[Siumut]] 1, [[Inuit Ataqatigiit]] 1. ==Judicial branch== High Court or Landsret. == Administrative divisions == {{main|Administrative divisions of Greenland}} == Diplomatic representations == With Denmark having responsibility for Greenland's international affairs, other countries do not have direct diplomatic representation in Greenlandâ€”their embassies or consulates in Denmark are responsible for their relations with Greenland and their citizens in Greenland. Greenland is represented internationally by the embassies and consulates of Denmark, although Greenland does directly participate in some Nordic organisations{{Which|date=January 2011}} which provide membership for dependent territories. ==See also== *[[Greenlandic independence]] *[[Greenlandic self-government referendum, 2008]] *[[Arctic cooperation and politics]] *[[Arctic policy of Denmark]] ===International organization participation=== *[[Nordic Council]] *[[Nordic Investment Bank]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== ; Government * [http://uk.nanoq.gl/ Greenland Home Rule] ''official government website'' (in English) * [http://www.greenland.com/ Greenland.com] from the Greenland Tourism & Business Council * [http://www.stat.gl/ Statistics Greenland] {{Europe topic|Politics of}} {{North America topic|Politics of}} [[Category:Politics of Greenland| ]]
